text: Earth and Planetary Science Letters 269 (2008) 309–325

Pore pressure penetrometers document high overpressure near the seafloor
where multiple submarine landslides have occurred on the continental slope,
offshore Louisiana, Gulf of Mexico

P.B. Flemings a,⁎, H. Long b,1, B. Dugan c, J. Germaine d, C.M. John e, J.H. Behrmann f, D. Sawyer a,
IODP Expedition 308 Scientists

a John A. and Katherine G. Jackson School of Geosciences, The University of Texas at Austin, 1 University Station C1100, Austin, TX 78712-0254, USA
b Department of Energy and Mineral Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA
c Department of Earth Science, Rice University, Houston, TX 77005, USA
d Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA
e Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843, USA
f IFM-GEOMAR, Wischhofstr. 1-3, 24148 Kiel, Germany
Received 2 July 2007; received in revised form 29 November 2007; accepted 1 December 2007

Editor: M.L. Delaney
Available online 8 April 2008
Abstract

Overpressures measured with pore pressure penetrometers during Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 308 reach 70% and
60% of the hydrostatic effective stress (k4 ¼
uuh
ð
Þ
r0
vh
ð
Þ ) in the first 200 meters below sea floor (mbsf) at Sites U1322 and U1324, respectively, in the
deepwater Gulf of Mexico, offshore Louisiana. High overpressures are present within low permeability mudstones where there have been
multiple, very large, submarine landslides during the Pleistocene. Beneath 200 mbsf at Site U1324, pore pressures drop significantly: there are no
submarine landslides in this mixture of mudstone, siltstone, and sandstone. The penetrometer measurements did not reach the in situ pressure at
the end of the deployment. We used a soil model to determine that an extrapolation approach based on the inverse of square route of time (1=
ﬃt
p )
requires much less decay time to achieve a desirable accuracy than an inverse time (1/t) extrapolation. Expedition 308 examined how rapid and
asymmetric sedimentation above a permeable aquifer drives lateral fluid flow, extreme pore pressures, and submarine landslides. We interpret that
the high overpressures observed are driven by rapid sedimentation of low permeability material from the ancestral Mississippi River. Reduced
overpressure at depth at Site U1324 suggests lateral flow (drainage) whereas high overpressure at Site U1322 requires inflow from below: lateral
flow in the underlying permeable aquifer provides one mechanism for these observations. High overpressure near the seafloor reduces slope
stability and provides a mechanism for the large submarine landslides and low regional gradient (2°) offshore from the Mississippi delta.

Keywords: IODP Expedition 308; overpressure; slope stability; submarine landslide; penetrometer; shallow water flow
1. Introduction

Overpressures, pore pressures in excess of hydrostatic, play a
critical role in geologic processes. Overpressures reduce the

⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +1 512 475 9520.
E-mail address: pflemings@jsg.utexas.edu (P.B. Flemings).
1 Now at ExxonMobil Upstream Research Company, 1320 Buffalo Speedway,
Houston, TX 77098, USA.
www.elsevier.com/locate/epsl

component of normal stress along faults and landslide detachments,
which provides a mechanism for large thrusts and submarine
landslides (Hubbert and Rubey, 1959). Overpressures may control
the taper angle of accretionary prisms (Davis et al., 1983; Saffer and
Bekins, 2002). Overpressures drive natural hydraulic fracturing and
account for dike emplacement and sandstone injection (Hubbert
and Willis, 1972; Boehm and Moore, 2002).
In young sedimentary basins, the most common source
of overpressure is rapid sedimentation of low permeability

material. When compressible low permeability rocks are rapidly
loaded, they cannot drain their pore fluid; as a result, the pore
fluid bears some of the applied load and overpressure results
(Gibson, 1958; Bethke, 1986). We have suggested that rapid
asymmetric loading of low permeability material above a
permeable aquifer induces focused flow within the aquifer,
which elevates pressure where the overburden is thin and causes
submarine landslides (Dugan and Flemings, 2000), mud
volcanoes (Seldon and Flemings, 2005), and the migration of
hydrocarbons (Flemings et al., 2002). Recently, Kvalstad et al.
(2005) suggested that the giant Storegga Slide was triggered by
this process.
The models described above are generally based on
theoretical analysis, indirect measurements of pressure based

Fig. 1. (A) The Mars–Ursa region is located 95 km (60 miles) south of the Mississippi River on the continental slope (National Geophysical Data Center, 1998).
(B) The bathymetry in the Mars-Ursa study area, derived from 3-D seismic data, lies between 800 and 1400 m (50 m contours are shown). The Mars and Ursa tension-
leg platforms are located with red rectangles. The 899-1 well (red circle) encountered overpressure and flow to the seafloor when the Blue Unit was penetrated during
industry drilling in 1995. IODP Expedition 308 Sites are delineated with yellow circles. Cross section A-A' is located in Fig. 2.

on compaction state, or direct measurements of pressure in
permeable horizons (Flemings et al., 2002). To verify this
behavior, we need to directly measure the spatial variation in
pore pressure in low permeability formations. Pore pressure
penetrometers, which are inserted directly into mudrocks to
measure pore pressure in minutes to hours, provide an exciting
approach to make these measurements (Davis et al., 1997;
Taylor et al., 2000; Long et al., 2007). This technique is
providing insight into how fluid flow, sedimentation, and slope
instability couple near the sea floor (Ostermeier et al., 2001,
2002; Orange et al., 2003).
IODP Expedition 308 was dedicated to the study of flow
focusing. We drilled three locations (Sites U1322, U1323, and
U1324) on the continental slope of the Gulf of Mexico, offshore

Louisiana in approximately 1000 meters of water depth (Fig. 1).
In this region, the ancestral Mississippi River rapidly deposited
fine grained sediment asymmetrically above a permeable
sandstone (the Blue Unit) (Fig. 2). Pore pressures, as measured
at the Ursa Platform, approximately 10 kilometers north of
our drilling locations, were already known to reach 50% of
the hydrostatic effective stress (k4 ¼ uuh
ð
Þ
r0
vh
ð
Þ ¼ 0:5) (Ostermeier
et al., 2001, 2002). Our goal was to document the vertical and
lateral variation in pressure and physical properties in this

Fig. 2. (A) East-West seismic cross section A-A' (located in Fig. 1B). (B) Interpreted cross section A-A'. Light and dark gray represent mud-rich levee, rotated
channel-margin slides, and hemipelagic drape; yellow represents sand-rich channel fill. The Blue Unit (light blue) is composed of sand (yellow) and mud (blue). Mass
transport deposits (MTDs) have occurred in the mud-rich levee deposits above the Blue Unit. Detachment surfaces at the base of the MTDs are colored red. Seismically
mapped surfaces (e.g. ‘S10’) are defined in Flemings et al. (2006a).

system and thereby learn how rapid and asymmetric sedimenta-
tion above a permeable aquifer drives lateral fluid flow, extreme
pore pressures, and submarine landslides.
We present pore pressure penetrometer measurements made
during IODP Expedition 308. We document vertical and lateral
variation in overpressure between Sites U1322 and U1324:
overpressures reach 60% of the hydrostatic effective stress
(k4 ¼
uuh
ð
Þ
r0
vh
ð
Þ ¼ 0:6) at Site U1322 and 70% at Site U1324
(u=pore pressure, uh=hydrostatic pore pressure, and σ'vh is

the vertical effective stress if pore pressure is hydrostatic). One-
dimensional modeling is used to illustrate that there is a sink for
fluid flow (drainage) in the deeper parts of Site U1324 whereas
the high pressure gradient at Site 1322 can only be explained if
there is a source of fluid flow from depth. Lateral flow in the
underlying Blue Unit is the most likely candidate for this result.
High overpressures are located within low permeability silty
claystones where there have been multiple, very large, submarine
landslides. High overpressures near the seafloor may provide an
explanation for the large submarine landslides and the low
regional gradient (2 degrees) offshore from the Mississippi delta.
2. Geology of the Ursa Basin

The Mars–Ursa salt-withdrawal basin (the “Ursa Basin“) is
located 210 km south–southeast of New Orleans, Louisiana
(USA), on the northeastern Gulf of Mexico continental slope

Fig. 3. IODP Site U1324. A) Depth in meters below sea floor (mbsf). B) Lithology. Mass Transport Deposits (MTDs) are delineated in purple, siltstones in orange,
sandstones in yellow, and mudstone in green. C) Gamma Ray (GR) from logging while drilling (LWD) data. D) Resistivity log (RES) log. E) Porosity log interpreted
from shipboard moisture and density (MAD) measurements (solid symbols). Porosity interpreted from logging while drilling (LWD) bulk density log assuming a grain
density of 2.74 g/cc (orange line). F) Overpressure (u⁎) using the 1=
ﬃt
p method (Fig. 9; Table 1, Supplementary data). Overpressure measured during drilling (‘PWD’)
is shown with solid line. The grey dashed line is our best estimate of the in situ pressure with depth. Overpressures (u⁎) are calculated by subtracting the hydrostatic
pressure (uh) from the measured pressure (u). uh is calculated assuming a pore fluid density (ρw) of 1.024 g/cc (uh=ρwgz). σvh' is the hydrostatic effective stress
(σvh'=σv−uh). The overburden stress (σv) is calculated by integrating shipboard-derived core density measurements.

(Fig. 1A.). Late Pleistocene deposition from the ancestral
Mississippi River is recorded by a southward bulge in the 500
and 1000 m bathymetric contours. The Mars Ridge, a prominent
north–south-trending bathymetric high, bounds the study area
to the west (Fig. 1B).
Late Pleistocene shelf, shelf-margin, and turbidite deposits
sourced from the Mississippi River are termed the Eastern
Depositional Complex (Winker and Booth, 2000). These strata
accumulated during Marine Isotope Stages (MIS) 2–4 in
response to late Wisconsinan continental glaciation (Winker
and Booth, 2000; Winker and Shipp, 2002; Flemings et al.,
2006b). They overlie the MIS 5 condensed section that contains
the extinction events of the planktonic foraminifer Globorotalia
flexuosa (70 ka) and the calcareous nannofossil Pontosphaera 1
(~70 ka) (Styzen, 1996; Winker and Booth, 2000).
In the Ursa Basin, Sawyer et al. (2007) used three-
dimensional seismic data and industry well logs to divide

these strata into the sand-prone Blue Unit and overlying mud-
prone leveed-channel deposition (Fig. 2). Turbidites within the
Blue Unit were deposited in a topographic low that extended
200 km to the east and west and 100 km to the north and south
(Winker and Stancliffe, 2007). The overlying leveed-channel
systems contain channels and bounding levees. The Ursa
Canyon channel–levee system immediately overlies the Blue
Unit, whereas the Southwest Pass Canyon channel–levee
system is younger and lies west of the Ursa Canyon (Fig. 2).
Mudstones that overlie the Southwest Pass Canyon record
deposition from leveed channels that lay further to the west,
outside of the study area (Fig. 2B). Multiple Mass Transport
Deposits (MTDs) are present in the leveed-channel deposits;
they are internally seismically transparent, have a large negative
seismic reflection at their base, and are bounded by nearly
vertical side walls (Fig. 2).
We drilled to just above the Blue Unit at Sites U1322,
U1323, and U1324 (Fig. 2). We did not core or make in situ
pressure measurements at Site U1323 because drilling was

Fig. 4. IODP Site U1322. A) Depth in meters below sea floor (mbsf). B) Lithologic section. Mass Transport Deposits (MTDs) are delineated in purple, siltstones in
orange, and sandstones in yellow, and mudstone in green. C) Gamma Ray (GR) from logging while drilling (LWD) data. D) Resistivity log (RES) log. E) Porosity log
interpreted from shipboard moisture and density (MAD) measurements (solid symbols). Porosity interpreted from logging while drilling (LWD) bulk density log
assuming a grain density of 2.74 g/cc (orange line). F) Overpressure (u⁎) using the 1=
ﬃt
p method (Fig. 9; Table 1, Supplementary data). Overpressure measured during
drilling when overpressured sands were encountered at Site U1323 is illustrated with a star (Flemings et al., 2006a). The grey dashed line is our best estimate of the in
situ pressure with depth. The ‘?' at the deepest DVTPP measurement (square) illustrates that this measurement lies off the trend delineated by the dashed line. We
interpret that this low pressure results from pressure dissipation in the underlying Blue Unit caused by industry drilling (see text for discussion). Overpressures (u⁎) are
calculated by subtracting the hydrostatic pressure (uh) from the measured pressure (u). uh is calculated assuming a pore fluid density (ρw) of 1.024 g/cc (uh=ρwgz).
σvh' is the hydrostatic effective stress (σvh'=σv−uh). The overburden stress (σv) is calculated by integrating shipboard-derived core density measurements.

abandoned at a depth of 242 mbsf after we encountered severely
overpressured sands that induced flow of water and unconso-
lidated sand to the sea floor (Flemings et al., 2006a). At Site
U1324, we encountered silty claystone to a depth of 400 m
below seafloor (mbsf) (Fig. 3B). Beneath this we encountered
silty claystone interbedded with beds of silt and very-fine sand.
The silts and very-fine sands record levee deposition proximal
to the Southwest Pass Canyon. At Site U1322, we encountered
only silty claystone (Fig. 4B). Mass transport deposits contain
faults, steeply dipping strata, and ‘s’ shaped folds (Flemings
et al., 2006a; Dugan et al., 2007; Sawyer et al., 2007). The mass
transport deposits comprise half of the stratigraphic section
(purple bedding, Fig. 4B) at Site U1322 whereas at Site U1324,
there are only three mass transport deposits present (Fig. 3B).
Porosity declines from 80% to 55% within the first 50 mbsf
at both sites (Figs. 3E and 4E). At Site U1324, between 50 mbsf
and 550 mbsf, the mudstone porosity declines from 55% to
42%; beneath 550 mbsf, porosity declines from 42% to 37% at
the bottom of the hole (620 mbsf). In the mudstones, resistivity

increases as porosity decreases (Fig. 3D). In the silts and very
fine sandstones at Site U1324, resistivity is lower, either due to
borehole washout or lower tortuosity in the pores. At Site
U1322, between 50 and 100 mbsf, the porosity gradually
declines to 50%. Beneath this, the porosity is approximately
constant. Resistivity also increases with decreasing porosity at
Site U1322 (Fig. 4D).
Porosity and resistivity are low within mass transport
deposits (purple lithologic units, Figs. 3B and 4B). The most
striking example of this is between 91 and 125 mbsf at Site
U1322 (Fig. 4D and E) where porosity declines to the base of
the mass transport deposit and then jumps abruptly by 5
porosity units. The densification of mass transport deposits
relative to their bounding sediments is attributed to the effect of
shearing on the soil (Piper et al., 1984; Prior et al., 1984; Dugan
et al., 2007; Sawyer et al., 2007).
3. Pore pressure measurements

We used the Davis–Villinger Temperature/Pressure Probe
(DVTPP) (Moore et al., 2001; Tréhu et al., 2003), and a tool that
we developed, the Temperature-Two-Pressure Probe (T2P)
(Flemings et al., 2006b) to measure in situ pressure (Fig. 5). The
T2P measures the pressure at its shaft and tip (Fig. 5). Its
geometry is similar to Fugro–McClelland's tapered Piezoprobe
(Ostermeier et al., 2001; Long et al., 2007). The DVTPP
diameter is significantly larger than the T2P diameter and it is
tapered (Fig. 5). We describe the results from Site U1324 and

Fig. 5. The DVTPP and T2P pore pressure penetrometers have different geometries. The DVTPP has a long, tapered tip that extends beyond the constant diameter
shaft. The pressure port is located 100 mm above the tip. The T2P has a tapered extension piece 223 mm long which fits onto the end of a standard 36 mm diameter
cone rod. It measures pore pressure at its narrow tip and at the larger diameter shaft behind the narrow tip.

Site U1322 (Table 1, Supplementary data). Long et al. (in
review-a) describe the details of each deployment and how the
tools were calibrated.
In an ideal, ‘Type I’, deployment, the pressure peaks during
insertion and subsequently declines with time (Fig. 6A). Dis-
sipation times ranged from 25 to 93 min with an average
duration of approximately 60 min (Table 1, Supplementary
data). The T2P shaft pressure declines more slowly and is much
higher than the tip pressure at the end of the deployment
(Fig. 6). Because the shaft has a much larger diameter than the
tip, it deforms a larger region around the probe: the elevated
pressure due to the shaft deformation takes more time to
dissipate. The T2P and DVTPP deployments were in very
similar lithologies, yet the degree of dissipation in the DVTPP is
less than that of the T2P tip (Fig. 6A). This is also due to the
geometry of the penetrometers. The DVTPP tip is significantly
larger than that of the T2P and it tapers to become even thicker
behind the tip (Fig. 5); as a result, it disturbs a greater region
around the penetrometer than does the T2P tip and its
dissipation time is greater. Long et al. (2007) compare the
DVTPP and the T2P geometries and their consequent behavior
during insertion and dissipation.
The penetrometer is pushed into the formation with the drill
string and then the drill string is immediately raised to decouple
the penetrometer from the effects of ship heave. During many
deployments, the penetrometer was slightly dislodged when the
drill string was raised (Fig. 6B). In this situation, the measured
pressure drops abruptly when the bit is raised (a ‘Type II’

deployment). This pressure drop is associated with rapid
temperature increase and tool movement (Flemings et al.,
2005; Long et al., in review-a). In Type IIA deployments, the
pressure rebounds immediately after tool extraction and
subsequently decays (Type IIA, Fig. 6B). We interpret that the
last recorded pressure for Type IIA deployments is an upper
bound for the in situ pressure because the pressure is still
subsiding at the end of the deployment. In contrast, in Type IIB
deployments the pressure keeps building after the bit is raised
(Type IIB, Fig. 6B).
3.1. Extrapolation of pressure decays

Unfortunately, there is no simple analytical approach to
extrapolate partial pressure dissipation data to interpret the in
situ pressure. Models that describe the pore pressure response to
penetration and the subsequent pressure decay rely on coupling
the geometry of the penetration with a soil model that describes

(MPa)
Δui
(MPa)
±5% error bar
(MPa)

elastic–plastic soil behavior (Randolph and Wroth, 1979;
Whittle et al., 2001; Long et al., 2007). These approaches
require extensive geotechnical testing of the soil that is
penetrated to establish the appropriate parameters.
In lieu of developing a soil model for each penetrometer
deployment, an empirical extrapolation approach is often used
to interpret in situ pressure from penetrometer data that record
only partial dissipation. The inverse time approach is most often
used (1/t, where t=dissipation time) (Davis et al., 1991; Fang
et al., 1993; Urgeles et al., 2000). In this technique, the data are
plotted on an inverse time scale and a linear extrapolation is
made based on the gradient of the last part of the data (Fig. 7B).
Unfortunately, there is no theoretical foundation to this
approach. Laboratory calibration chamber tests suggest that 1/t
extrapolation provides an accurate estimate of in situ pressure
(Lim et al., 2006). However, these tests were performed on
examples where the measured pressure had already dissipated by
more than 90% relative to the initial pressure disturbance. In

Fig. 6. Pressure records for the DVTPP and the T2P. Zero time is marked at the start of the dissipation phase of the deployment. Hydrostatic pressure (uh) at the
deployment depth (dash-dot line) is calculated assuming a seawater density of 1.024 g/cc. A) Type I deployments with type pressure dissipation curves. B) Type II
deployments: pressure drops rapidly due to tool dislodgement, after rebounds to certain level, pressure decays towards formation pressure (Type IIA); pressure drops
rapidly due to tool dislodgement and then builds up to formation pressure (Type IIB). Long et al. (in review-a) describe the details of each deployment.

contrast, Whittle et al. (2001) and Long et al. (2007) suggest that
the 1/t extrapolation overestimates the in situ pressure for low
permeability sediments.
We use a theoretical model of penetrometer dissipation to
compare two extrapolation techniques: 1/t and 1=

p . The
theoretical dissipation curves for the DVTPP and the T2P are

and shaft and the DVTPP are presented in dimensionless time T,
where T ¼ ct=R2
2 and R2 is the diameter of the T2P shaft: T is

used to describe the dissipation for material with any hydraulic

recover the actual dissipation time for any of the modeled
dissipations. The model results illustrate that the narrow diameter
T2P tip (#1) dissipates its pressure more rapidly than either the
T2P shaft (#2) or the DVTPP (#3) (Fig. 7A). The dissipation

3.2. Pore pressure profiles

We plot overpressure vs. depth beneath sea floor (mbsf)
(Figs. 3F, 4F, 9, and 10). Pore pressure (uo) equals the hydrostatic
pressure (uh) when overpressure (u⁎) is zero; pore pressure equals
the lithostatic stress (σv) when the overpressure (u⁎) equals the
hydrostatic effective stress (σvh'). σvh' is delineated with a solid
black line in each plot. We also use the overpressure ratio (λ⁎=(u0−
uh)/(σvh'))tocharacterizetherelationshipbetweentheporepressure
and the overburden stress. When λ⁎=0, there is no overpressure
whereas when λ⁎=1, pore pressure equals the overburden stress.

3.2.1. Site U1324
At Site U1324, above 200 mbsf, the final recorded over-
pressures cluster around the hydrostatic effective stress line
(σvh'). Beneath 200 mbsf, the last recorded overpressures are
less than σvh' (Fig. 9A). All of the final shaft T2P overpressures,
except one, exceed σvh' whereas the final tip pressures are
significantly less than σvh' (circles vs. triangles, Fig. 9A). As
described, there is a much greater dissipation at the narrow
diameter tip than the wide diameter shaft for a given amount of
time (Fig. 7A). Thus, the last measured pressures at the tip are
closer to the in situ pressure than the shaft. Unfortunately, there
were many more successful shaft measurements than tip
measurements; extrapolation is critical to interpret in situ
pressure from both the shaft measurements and the DVTPP
measurements.
In the 1/t extrapolation, pressures from Type I and Type IIA
deployments are lower than the last recorded pressures and all

Fig. 9. Pressure penetrometer measurements at Site U1324. A) Last recorded overpressure of the DVTPP and the T2P deployments. B) Overpressure estimated by 1/t
extrapolation. C) Overpressure estimated by 1=

p extrapolation. Error bars that represent +/−5% of the installation pressure are illustrated only for deep deployments
(see Table 1, Supplementary data, for all error estimates). Overpressures (u⁎) are calculated by subtracting the hydrostatic pressure (uh) from the measured pressure (u).
uh is calculated assuming a pore fluid density (ρw) of 1.024 g/cc (uh=ρwgz). σvh' is the hydrostatic effective stress (σvh'=σv−uh). The overburden stress (σv) is
calculated by integrating shipboard-derived core density measurements.

T2P shaft pressures are higher than the T2P tip pressures
(Fig. 9B vs. A). This suggests that the ending dissipation time
factor (T) is less than 50 (red dotted line intersects green dashed
line at T=~50 in Fig. 8B); in this regime, the modeled 1/t
extrapolation overpredicts in situ pressure by more than 5% of
the installation pressure (above the gray horizontal bar, Fig. 8B).
Pressures are generally the lowest with the 1=
ﬃt
p extrapola-
tion for Type I and Type IIA deployments (Fig. 9C). For the three
60-minute T2P deployments (#12 (50 mbsf), #13 (100 mbsf) and
#15 (200 mbsf) (Table 1, Supplementary data), the tip pressure
is very close to the shaft pressure. In addition, the tip pressure
estimated by 1=
ﬃt
p extrapolation are very similar (Fig. 9B vs. C).
Fig. 8B illustrates that the T2P tip and shaft pressure are equal at
T≈10 and at these conditions, the in situ pressure should be
approximately 0.07 du0=Dui lower than the 1=
ﬃt
p prediction.
T2P Deployment #16 at 300 mbsf (Fig. 6, Table 1, Supplemen-
tary data) is unique because it was the longest deployment
(90 minutes). The 1=
ﬃt
p extrapolation results in a shaft pressure
that is less than the tip pressure (Fig. 9C). In addition, the 1=
ﬃt
p

tip pressure lies between the tip and shaft pressures predicted
by the 1/t method (Table 1, Supplementary data).
Beneath 300 mbsf, there are only two reliable measurements
and these were made with the DVTPP. Deployment of the T2P
at these depths was unsuccessful because the tip broke in the
firm sediment. DVTPP #12 (608.2 mbsf) is a TypeIIB deployment
whereas DVTPP #15 (505 mbsf) is a Type IIA Deployment
(Table 1, Supplementary data, Fig. 9). Both deployments were
for approximately one hour. The 1=
ﬃt
p extrapolation suggests that
the in situ pressure is approximately 1 MPa+/−0.3 MPa.

Fig. 10. Overpressure measurements at Site U1322. A) Last recorded overpressure of the DVTPP and the T2P deployments. B) Overpressure estimated by 1/t
extrapolation. C) Overpressure estimated by 1=
ﬃt
p extrapolation. Error bars that represent +/−5% of the installation pressure are illustrated only for deep deployments
(see Table 1, Supplementary data, for all error estimates). Overpressures (u⁎) are calculated by subtracting the hydrostatic pressure (uh) from the measured pressure (u).
uh is calculated assuming a pore fluid density (ρw) of 1.024 g/cc (uh=ρwgz). σvh' is the hydrostatic effective stress (σvh'=σv−uh). The overburden stress (σv) is
calculated by integrating shipboard-derived core density measurements.

3.2.2. Site U1322
At Site U1322, only one T2P deployment and one DVTPP
deployment was of Type I quality (Fig. 10, red symbols). All of
the tip records of the T2P deployments except Deployment #24
(200 mbsf) are Type IIB whereas all of the shaft T2P
measurements except the shallowest deployment (T2P #27)
are Type IIA (Fig. 10, Table 1, Supplementary data). Not
surprisingly, all of the final recorded Type IIB pressures are
lower than the Type IIA pressures (Fig. 10A, green vs. blue
symbols). Above 200 mbsf, the last recorded overpressures are
greater than 50% of the hydrostatic effective stress (λ⁎N0.5)
(Fig. 10A). Below this, two DVTPP measurements are
approximately half of the hydrostatic effective stress (Fig. 10A).
The 1=
ﬃt
p extrapolations suggest that overpressures increase to
200 mbsf, at a gradient that is approximately 60% of the reduced
overburden stress (Fig. 10C). The deepest pore pressure measure-
ment that was made with the DVTPP is high quality (Type I) yet
has an anomalously low pressure (Fig. 10C, Table 1, Supplemen-
tary data).
4. Discussion

Figs. 3F and 4F illustrate the 1=
ﬃt
p extrapolations plotted
adjacent to the log and core measurements for Site U1324 and
Site U1322, respectively. We overlie on these data our estimate
of the in situ pressure profile (grey dashed line). We are guided
by the 1=
ﬃt
p
extrapolation. However, we also consider the
length of the deployments and our confidence in the calibration
(Long et al., in review-a).
4.1. Site U1324 pore pressure

The pore pressure profile can be divided into two regimes at
Site U1324. Above 200 mbsf, overpressures equal approxi-
mately 70% of the hydrostatic effective stress (λ⁎=0.7)
(Fig. 3F). These observations are compatible with pre-conso-
lidation stresses determined from uniaxial consolidation
measurements (Long, 2007; Long et al., in review-b). Beneath
200 mbsf, overpressures drop sharply and are approximately
equal to 1 MPa. Sample deformation at these deeper depths
results in ambiguous pre-consolidation stresses (Long, 2007;
Long et al., in review-b). Down hole pressures measured while
drilling varied between 1.2 and 1.4 MPa beneath 400 mbsf
(“PWD”, Fig. 3). When sands were penetrated, pressures
dropped relative to when mudstones were penetrated. We
interpret that this records flow from the borehole into the
permeable formation (circulation loss) and that the downhole
pressures are an upper bound to the formation pressure. The
mudstone porosity beneath 200 mbsf declines slowly but
continuously with depth (Fig. 3). This suggests that the effective
stress increases with depth and thus the overpressure declines
with depth as suggested by the pore pressure profile.
The overpressure distribution at Site U1324 is closely tied to
lithology. Above 300 mbsf, where overpressure is high, the
sediments are composed of monotonous hemipelagic silty
claystone (Fig. 3). At 305.7 mbsf, the first sand is encountered.
This massive fine-to medium sand is 1.1 m thick and is the
coarsest sand bed encountered at Site U1324. It underlies the first
decline in overpressure with depth that is recorded by DVTPP #13

Fig. 11. Non-dimensionalized overpressure (u⁎=rVvhðhÞ) vs. non-dimensional depth (mbsf/h) at A) Site U1324 and B) Site U1322. Gibson’s (1958) one dimensional
solutions for overpressure during constant sedimentation rate with no flow at the base are shown for different time factors (Tg) (solid black lines). Triangles record T2P
tip measurements, circles record T2P shaft measurements, and squares record DVTPP measurements. Red, blue, and green colored symbols refer to Type 1, Type IIA,
and Type IIB deployments as discussed in the text and presented in Table 1 (Supplementary data). All measurements are derived from the 1=
ﬃt
p extrapolation (Table 1,
Supplementary data). Grey dashed line records our interpretation of in situ pressure profile (see grey dashed lines in Figs. 3 and 4). The modeled overpressure is
controlled by Gibson’s time factor, Tg ¼ m2t=c where m is the sedimentation rate, t is total time (t) and c is hydraulic diffusivity. The shallow pressure data at Site
U1324 (mbsf/hb0.4) are compatible with a time factor (Tg) of approximately 4 whereas the deeper data are compatible with Tg between 0.25 and 1.0. At Site U1324,
where sedimentation rate is high, actual estimates of Tg equal 11 for mudstone and 1.0 for siltstone (Table 2, Supplementary data). At Site U1322, the pressure data are
compatible with Tg equal to 4. At this location, only mudstone was deposited, and the average sedimentation rate is much lower than at Site 1324: Tg is estimated to
equal 1.0 (Table 2, Supplementary data). Plots are in dimensionless coordinates, where mbsf/h is the depth below seafloor (mbsf) divided by the total depth (h=620
mbsf at U1324 and 250 mbsf at U1322). Overpressure (u*) is normalized by the hydrostatic effective stress at the base of the hole (σ′vh(h)).

at 250 mbsf (Table 1). This sand lies within the eastern levee of the
Southwest Pass Canyon, which is otherwise dominated by clay
and fine silt. It is truncated eastward between Sites U1324 and
U1323 by a mass transport complex and it extends to the south

and ultimately intersects the channel fill of Southwest Pass
Canyon. Its lateral continuity to the north and west is unknown.
Beneath this sand, where overpressure is constant, silty claystone
is interbedded with beds of silt and very-fine sand (Fig. 3).
4.2. Site U1322 pore pressure

We interpret a linear increase in overpressure from the
seafloor to 200 mbsf at Site U1322 (Fig. 4). T2P #24 (200 mbsf)
and DVTPP #18 (220 mbsf) are good measurements and we
have drawn a straight line from near the seafloor through these
data. The intervening data points all scatter around λ⁎=0.6. The
majority of these measurements are either Type IIB or only shaft
pressures were recorded (Table 1); we do not have enough
confidence to interpret these data in more detail. Pre-
consolidation stresses determined from uniaxial consolidation
measurements were made to a depth of 210 mbsf and suggest
λ⁎=0.6−0.7 (Long, 2007; Long et al., in review-b). Our results
are also similar to those presented by Ostermeier et al. (2000),
who reported a linear overpressure gradient with λ⁎=0.5 at the
Ursa Platform 10 km to the north of Site U1322 (Fig. 1). The
deepest measurement (DVTPP #19) is of high quality yet has an
anomalously low pressure (0.25 MPa), which is contrary to the
general trend of increasing overpressure with depth. We explore
this further in the ensuing section.
At Site U1323, which is 5 km to the east of Site U1322
(Fig. 2), we encountered an overpressured and permeable
formation that flowed water and unconsolidated sand into the
borehole at 200 mbsf (Flemings et al., 2006a). This resulted in
an increase in bottom hole pressure of 1.0 MPa. Ostermeier
et al. (2002) suggest that the increase in hole pressure due to
these flows can approximate the downhole pressure encoun-
tered and we note that 1 MPa overpressure is very similar to the
penetrometer derived pressures (‘star’ in Fig. 4).
4.3. Overpressure origin and hydrodynamic flow field

Rapid deposition of low permeability sediment generates pore
fluid overpressure because the fluid can not escape as the
sediment compacts (Gibson, 1958; Gordon and Flemings, 1998).
We use Gibson's (1958) analytical solution for sedimentation
above an impermeable base to illustrate that the shallow
overpressures at Site U1324 are compatible with those expected
from one-dimensional sedimentation whereas the overpressures
at Site U1322 are not (Fig. 11, Table 2, Supplementary data). The
degree of overpressure is controlled by Gibson's time factor,
Tg ¼ m2t=c, where m is the sedimentation rate, t is total time (t)
and c is hydraulic diffusivity. The average sedimentation rate from
the seafloor to the top of the Blue Unit is 12 mm/year at Site U1324
and 3.6mm/yr at Site U1322 and the total time spanis 50,000 years
(Flemings et al., 2006a) (Table 2, Supplementary data). Ursa
mudstones have hydraulic diffusivities of 2×10−8 m2/s whereas
siltstones have diffusivities greater than 2×10−7 m2/s (Long,
2007; Long et al., in review-b).
At Site U1324, where the sedimentation rate is high, Tg=11
for mudstone and 1 for siltstone (Table 2, Supplementary data).
A time factor of 11 produces significant overpressure with a
basal value of λ⁎ greater than 0.6 and even higher values of λ⁎
closer to the seafloor (Fig. 11A, Table 2, Supplementary data).
In contrast, Tg=1 produces a basal value of λ⁎ less than 0.3. We
interpret that at Site U1324, rapid deposition of fine grained low
permeability mudstone in the upper 200 mbsf generated the

high overpressures present. The interbedded silts and sands
beneath 300 mbsf have a significantly higher hydraulic
diffusivity than the overlying mudstones and as a result, there
is not a significant overpressure gradient in this zone.
At Site U1324, the overpressure beneath 200 mbsf is less
than the overpressure above (Fig. 3F). Given one-dimensional
flow, flow is driven down the overpressure gradient; thus there
is downward flow from the overpressured section above
200 mbsf. However, one-dimensional sedimentation of homo-
genous material where flow exits only at the seafloor generates
overpressures that increase with depth (Fig. 11, Supplementary
data). Thus, there must be some flow pathway that drains the
lower section relative to the upper section. An obvious
candidate is lateral flow along the permeable silts, sands within
the drilled section, or lateral flow in the underlying Blue Unit
(e.g. Dugan and Flemings, 2000).
At Site U1322, where only mudstone is deposited and the
average sedimentation rate is much lower than at Site U1324,
Tg equals 1.0 (Table 2, Supplementary data). This results in
a basal value of λ⁎ less than 0.3, which is much less than the
overpressures observed at Site U1322 (λ⁎=0.6) (Fig. 11B,
Supplementary data). To account for the high overpressures
at Site U1322, there must be a basal source of fluid: the
obvious candidate is the underlying permeable sands of the Blue
Unit.
The low overpressure recorded by DVTPP #19 at 238 mbsf,
near the base of Site U1322 (Fig. 4F, Table 1, Supplementary
data) is our most perplexing measurement. Our present
interpretation is that the low pressure measured with a single
penetrometer measurement at the base of the hole is caused by
penetration and drainage of fluid from an upper isolated
compartment of the Blue Unit that was penetrated during
industry drilling. Ostermeier et al. (2000) made penetrometer
measurements in 1991 at the Ursa Platform 10 km to the north
(Fig. 1) and they did do not report any decline in overpressure as
the Blue Unit was approached. Since that time, many wells have
penetrated the Blue Sand and significant volumes of water and
unconsolidated sand were expelled at the sea floor (Alberty,
2000). An important example is the MC-810-1 well, drilled in
1995, which had large volumes of flow to the surface and was
located less than 1 km to the south of Site U1322 (Fig. 1). Given
pressure diffusivities for siltstone and mudstone of 2×10−7 to
10−8 m2/s (Table 2, Supplementary data), and 15 years since
drilling, 10% of an instantaneous pressure drop present in the
Blue Unit sandstone will have penetrated a distance of 4.6–
16.2 m into the mudstone, respectively (Turcotte and Schubert,
1982). Based on seismic data, we estimate that Site U1322 was
drilled to 20 m above the Blue Unit; however, we do not know
the lithology.
4.4. Implications of shallow overpressure

We have documented severe overpressures in the first 200 m
below seafloor in the Ursa Basin. This contrasts the historical
view that overpressure is encountered only at greater depths
(Dickinson, 1953). The absence of overpressure at shallow
depths on the continental shelf inspired theoretical models

suggesting that mudstones could only become pressure seals
after their porosity was sufficiently reduced by burial (Mello
et al., 1994). In fact, outboard of deltaic systems on the con-
tinental slope, rapid deposition of fine grained sediment create
ideal conditions for overpressure generation (Ostermeier et al.,
2001, 2002; Orange et al., 2003).
A striking result of our study is that submarine landslides all
lie within zones of high overpressures (λ⁎N0.6) (purple zones,
Figs. 3B and Fig. 4B). It is well known that elevated pore
pressure increases the risk of landslides and this can be
quantified by limit equilibrium analysis (Dugan and Flemings,
2002). For a constant friction angle (ϕf), and sediment with no
cohesion, the factor of safety (FS) is proportional to the over-
pressure ratio,

FS ¼
tan /f
sin h cos h cos2h  k4


;
ð1Þ

where θ is the surface slope. Given the 2 degree slope at Ursa
and a friction angle common for mudstone of 30° (Lambe and
Whitman, 1969), FS=9.6 and 4.9, for values of λ⁎ equal to 0.6
(Site U1322) and 0.7 (Site U1324), respectively. In contrast
FS=16.5 in both locations if no overpressure is present; thus
overpressure greatly increases the probability of slope failure at
these locations. To achieve a factor of safety equal to 1.0, λ⁎
must equal 0.93 at both locations. This is not observed at present.
However, we have assumed only an average sedimentation rate for
the mudstones above the Blue Unit. If the sedimentation rate was
higher during the Pleistocene, as it most likely was, then the
overpressure and the probability of slope failure will also have been
higher (e.g. (Dugan and Flemings, 2002)). Alternatively, given the
current pressures, a slope of 10 degrees at Site U1324 or 12° at Site
U1322 produces a factor of safety (FS) equal to 1. It is difficult to
construct a geological scenario that would generate these extreme
slopes in the late Pleistocene.
The northern continental slope in the Gulf of Mexico has the
lowest gradient of the U.S. continental margins and it has the
largest submarine landslides (McAdoo et al., 2000). We
interpret that overpressures pre-condition the slope for failure:
where overpressures are present, landslides are more likely to be
triggered by earthquakes or perhaps very large storms. Thus,
high pore pressure near the seafloor plays a significant role in
controlling where submarine landslides occur and controlling
the topographic gradient of the continental slope.
5. Conclusion

We used 23 pore pressure penetrometer deployments to
estimate the vertical profile of in situ pressure at IODP Expedition
308 Sites U1324 and U1322. The penetrometer measurements did
not reach the in situ pressure at the end of the deployment. We
used a soil model to determine that an extrapolation approach
based on the inverse of square root of time 1=
ﬃt
p requires much
less decay time to achieve a desirable accuracy than an inverse
time (1/t) extrapolation.
At IODP Site U1324, overpressures are 70% of the
hydrostatic effective stress to a depth of 200 m below sea
floor (λ⁎=~0.7). Beneath this overpressures drop significantly

and are approximately equal to 1 MPa to a depth of 600 mbsf.
The shallow overpressures are present in very rapidly deposited
low permeability mudstone whereas the deeper zone where the
overpressure is lower is composed of interbedded siltstone,
mudstone, and sandstone. At IODP Site U1322, the over-
pressures are 60% of the hydrostatic effective stress (λ⁎=0.6)
to 200 mbsf through a uniform section of silty clay. We interpret
that the high overpressures observed are driven by rapid sedi-
mentation of low permeability material from the ancestral
Mississippi River. High overpressures near the seafloor pro-
vide an explanation for the large submarine landslides and the
low regional gradient (2°) offshore from the Mississippi delta.
